text: Dr. Lindzen's stances seemed logically inconsistent. He sometimes argued that there was no consensus among scientists and other times agreed that there was a consensus but claimed that they were biased or pressured to affirm man-made climate change, but then couldn't point to a party that would pressure them, nor a motivation for doing so. There were also points in the conversation where he disagreed on whether climate change is man-made, but then during other parts agreed with the importance of us acting on the potential risk, but simply disagreed with the solutions being proposed (e.g. didn't think "symbolic" solutions such as windmills would make a difference but implied that more robust solutions would). After watching the whole interview, I still couldn't tell you what his main argument is other than he doesn't think we should worry about something that most scientists think we should.

text:
Probably the same thing as he did back when the interview occurred. 

We recently had bush fires which were blamed on climate change (by the alarmists) but were later found to be the work of arsonists. Not to forget that a lot of fuel on the ground that makes the fires so destructive is managed incorrectly because of lunatic ideological nonsense from environmentalist parties such as the Greens. 
Interesting how the indigenous folks knew what to do: 

__"Aboriginal people in the Kimberley have been undertaking traditional fire management for thousands of years. However, with the onset of colonisation and the removal of Aboriginal people from traditional lands, traditional burning was largely stopped during the twentieth century. This led to the emergence of large, uncontrolled wildfires, usually occurring late in the dry season and destroying important ecosystems and habitats. Often these late dry season wildfires impact grazing pasture, infrastructure and other assets.

In the last 25 years, with the introduction of native title and the recognition that western fire prevention methods have not been working effectively, we are now seeing a reinvigoration of traditional fire management in the Kimberley and all across northern Australia."__

Neither the sun nor El Nino care what we do. 

It's cost us trillions thus far to change nothing which is what the emminent scientist warned us about. What an achievement to read that elderly people in my country have to choose between putting their heaters on to keep warm in winter versus eating properly. How wonderful to treat those people that helped shape my country's prosperity like third world citizens because some ideological driven morons decided to impose tariffs on non-renewable power generation.

What I am always disappointed in these debates is what are the impact of spending that money and the restriction they institute on special the poor. For 5,000 years of civilization, nothing changed in the much outside of the use of horses to improve lives which were imaginable more terrible than today. Then cheap power was harassed and for at least the west a huge improvement in health, life, and that quality.

I always want to know science not opinions. Both scientists agree on but when confronted with those the alarmists drop back on unqualified surveys rather than sitting how the climate and the greenhouse actually works. That's because it is very complex where only a very part involves CO2.  The increase in CO2 does not have a linear impact for example but much least because of how it works in the greenhouse process works. Water vapor and ocean interactions are the big players and are not well understood.

If you are a climate alarmist study the sciences and for god, sake don't trust AI-driven models as those have an awful history of correlation with cause and effect. At least when I was involved in that business.

text:
Wow, when people feel like a "conspiracy" or political lying is happening, they sure do strongly oppose it. To a degree that makes sense, but in this case the potential risk is too great.

Let's imagine there was only a 25% (1 in 4) chance that climate change could spiral out of control if humans don't change their ways, and 75% chance it's false propaganda. Merely a 25% chance of danger. Would that risk be worth ignoring? Isn't that enough risk to raise serious alarms? Let's do a cost/benefit analysis:
-Cost of ignoring alarms: Famine, flooding, ocean acidification, mass extinctions of animal species, food shortages, more pollution, etc.
-Benefit of ignoring alarms: Money saved by not investing in renewable sustainable resources.

I would say the cost is so much greater than the benefits that it is worth taking the alarms seriously. Remember, we don't have a plan B; there's no "alternate Earth". If this one becomes less hospitable then there's nowhere else to go. Many people will suffer and die.

I think a good analogy would be the brake lines in your teenage child's car. Imagine several strange people told you that someone cut the brake lines of your kid's car during the night. Let's say you think there's a 75% chance they're delusional and a 25% chance they might be right. Would the risk be worth it to ignore? Would you let your kid drive to class without taking it to the shop first, even it'll cause you to be late?

Even if there's a relatively small chance, the danger of being wrong is potentially catastrophic. It's not worth the risk to downplay the warnings of so many scientists. Maybe you personally hate the liberal hippie SJW morons that you think are parroting the climate change alarmism, but that hatred does not mean it would be a good idea to ignore the warnings. We must not confuse contrarianism with wisdom. We're better safe than sorry, right?
author: TBM

text:
Some underlying objective truths;
1. People can live indefinitely in environments that range between roughly 40 degrees F and 95 degrees F (4 and 35 degrees C), ‚Äòif ‚Äô the latter temperature occurs at no more than 50 percent relative humidity. The maximum temperature pushes upward when it's less humid, because lower water content in the air makes it easier to sweat, and thus, keep cool (wet bulb temperatures).
2. For plants, including the major crops (of which over 70% of total nutritional intake ¬†come from 3 crops), the limits are more finely balanced. Transpiration is the process by which moisture is carried through plants from roots to small pores on the underside of leaves, where it changes to vapor and is released to the atmosphere. This is how nutrient uptake occurs and is essential for plant viability. Sustained periods at temperatures of 40C or higher where humidity is also high and/or evening do not cool sufficiently becomes non-viable
3. As the atmospheric CO2 level increases above 400ppm, the nutritional content of most major crops start to decrease. As does human cognitive functions. We have now hit 410ppm.
4. Atmospheric CO2 emits an increasing amount of infrared energy, 0.2 Watts per square meter per decade. Roughly, this means CO2 achieves maximum efficiency as a GHG, 10 years after initial emission.
5. Water vapor in the troposhere accounts for the most GHG in the atmosphere. Atmospheric water vapor increases by roughly 7% per 1 degree C of warming. Australia just reported 1 degree anomaly from 1910 - 2018 in their annual state of the climate report.
6. In the first decade or so after its release, methane is 86x more potent than carbon dioxide, with an initial burst effect. It then decays into carbon dioxide (reacts with negatively charged Hydroxyl ions), where it persists for centuries.
7. Nitrous Oxide, N2O is roughly 300x times more potent as a GHG than CO2 and is emitted via microbial release, primarily from use of fertilizers and dairy farming and other industrial activity.
8. Sulphur hexafluoride, SF6 is widely used in the electrical industry to prevent short circuits (wind, solar and the like). It has the highest GHG potential of any known substance, 23,500x more potent than CO2. Being synthetic with no natural pathway for removal, it persists as a GHG for over 1000 years, yet 75% growth in emissions is predicted by 2030.
9. More than 90% of the warming that has happened on Earth over the last 50 years or so has occurred in the oceans.
10. The same amount of energy required to melt 1kg of ice at 0 degrees C to produce 1kg of water (phase transition), could be used to raise the temperature of that 1kg of water from 0 degrees C to 79.8 degrees C.
11. Solar irradiation has been decreasing, as measured against the 11 year average, since around 1980. It will start to increase, although overall, it is of little net effect (whether considering Milankovitch or sun spot cycles).
author: Alex Gullen

text:
It‚Äôs not like we haven‚Äôt known for some time now...


By 1750 there was around 700 million people on Earth, 1804 a billion, 1850 1.2 billion. First steam engine was 1698 (i.e. coal powered), things were really swinging into action by 1750..


In the early 19th century Joseph Fourier showed that the atmosphere kept the Earth warmer than it would be if exposed directly to outer space. By 1860 John Tyndall, an Irish physicist, had found that a key to this warming lay in an interesting property of some atmospheric gases, including carbon dioxide. They were transparent to visible light but absorbed infrared radiation, which meant they let sunlight in but impeded heat from getting out.


In 1895, the Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius discovered that humans could enhance the greenhouse effect by making carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas.


By early 20th century, the GHG effect of CO2 from coal use was already established. In the 1960s, David Keeling demonstrated that human-caused carbon dioxide emissions are large enough to cause global warming (the Keeling curve) etc., etc.

text:
Because a little more CO2 can help plants grow, some people don't understand just how destructive adding more CO2, and warming the planet, and acidifying the ocean, and destabilizing the climate really is. Yes, in a controlled experiment in a greenhouse, more CO2 gets you more plant growth. That part is correct. But that experiment doesn't reflect the real-world ripple effects of global increases in CO2, meaning those experiments are useless for guiding policy. So how do natural systems actually work? In the real world, increased CO2 is causing global warming which in turn causes the atmosphere to hold more water (7% more for every 1 degree C increase in temperature), which is leading to the drying out of some ecosystems--for example, across the American west. The combination of warming and drier soils than has allowed for things like the beetle infestations in the Rockies. The combination of these factors has led to staggering die offs of forests, for example, >800 million "standing dead" trees in Colorado alone. This increase in dead trees makes forest fires worse, releasing even more CO2 into the atmosphere, thus causing even more warming and an acceleration of this kind of destruction. The dried out ground also releases more CO2, and the whole cycle leads to epic storms, floods, and droughts. Meanwhile, the warming has already made crops such as grains to have 5-8% less of key nutrients, thus promoting poor human health, overeating, or both. More broadly, pumping most of that heat and EXCESS CO2 human pumped into the atmosphere was absorbed by the oceans, making them warmer and 30% more acidic. Marine life isn't designed for these rapid changes in their ecosystem, and the last time the Earth warmed this rapidly, >90% of life in the oceans went extinct. THAT is where our reckless disruption of ecosystem balance is taking us: For example, half of the largest living thing on Earth--the 2400 mile-long Great Barrier Reef--already died in two events related to global warming and ocean acidification. Unless we reverse the damage we have done, virtually all or all coral reefs (the rainforests of the ocean) will be extinct by 2100. We are literally killing the oceans in a very direct way. 


Humans and all other living things on Earth evolved in an Earth that kept within a narrow range of average temperatures and with rather stable climate, and by pushing the system outside those parameters, we are setting in motion the "Sixth Extinction" of life on Earth. Not only does this mean killing off much of what we love about the natural world, human civilization is totally dependent of the health of the Earth's ecosystems, so unless we turn things around rapidly, humanity will witness in my children's lifetimes hundreds of millions to billions of human deaths due to our warming of the planet and destruction of the biosphere.

It's hard to face, but those ARE the facts on the ground. 

Take care.

text:
Not true, All ecosystems on Earth are currently better adapted to a world of around 300 ppm or even lower--where it's been for 800,000 years. If we want to save the Amazon, people everywhere need to eat less meat, which is the main reason the Amazon is being cut down. And in a world NOT adapted to higher CO2 levels, spiking them rapidly as we are doing, will lead to the disruption of ecosystems and mass extinctions. 


Yes, in a controlled experiment in a greenhouse, more CO2 gets you more plant growth. That part you have right. But that experiment doesn't reflect the real-world ripple effects of global increases in CO2, meaning those experiments are useless for guiding policy. So how do natural systems actually work? In the real world, increased CO2 is causing global warming which in turn causes the atmosphere to hold more water (7% more for every 1 degree C increase in temperature), which is leading to the drying out of ecosystems--for example, across the American west. The combination of warming and drier soils than has allowed for things like the beetle infestations in the Rockies. The combination of these factors has led to staggering die offs of forests, for example, 
>800 million "standing dead" trees in Colorado alone. This increase in dead trees makes forest fires worse, releasing even more CO2 into the atmosphere, thus causing even more warming and an acceleration of this kind of destruction. The dried out ground also releases more CO2, and the whole cycle leads to epic storms, floods, and droughts. Meanwhile, the warming has already made crops such as grains to have 5-8% less of key nutrients, thus promoting poor human health, overeating, or both. More broadly, pumping most of that heat and EXCESS CO2 human pumped into the atmosphere was absorbed by the oceans, making them warmer and 30% more acidic. Marine life isn't designed for these rapid changes in their ecosystem, and the last time the Earth warmed this rapidly, >90% of life in the oceans went extinct. THAT is where our reckless disruption of ecosystem balance is taking us: For example, half of the largest living thing on Earth--the 2400 mile-long Great Barrier Reef--already died in two events related to global warming and ocean acidification. Unless we reverse the damage we have done, virtually all or all coral reefs (the rainforests of the ocean) will be extinct by 2100. We are literally killing the oceans in a very direct way. 

Humans and all other living things on Earth evolved in an Earth that kept within a narrow range of average temperatures and with rather stable climate, and by pushing the system outside those parameters, we are setting in motion the "Sixth Extinction" of life on Earth. Not only does this mean killing off much of what we love about the natural world, human civilization is totally dependent of the health of the Earth's ecosystems, so unless we turn things around rapidly, humanity will witness in my children's lifetimes hundreds of millions to billions of human deaths due to our warming of the planet and destruction of the biosphere.

It's hard to face, but those ARE the facts on the ground. 

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text:
By interviewing a denier, Al Jazeera has simply fuelled the tidal wave of baseless conspiracy theories and pseudo-science promoted by social media. Lindzen‚Äôs views are not supported by any relevant science - they cannot be cast as scepticism when they have no basis in published science. Miles Allen‚Äôs responses were, for the most part, abysmal. Despite having relevant scientific expertise he failed to challenge the absurd bias conspiracy promoted by Lindzen and explain how the checks and balances integral to the scientific method severely limit interference by vested interests. Any scientist is free to publish their counter evidence on this issue in peer reviewed journals. Without exception, such counter evidence has been discredited by the scientific community. Further, Allen failed to challenge Lindzen‚Äôs conclusion that recent warming was insignificant and would continue to be so, despite exponential growth in CO2 emissions. This isn‚Äôt difficult - it is simple arithmetic. 
The impact of such ill informed debate is entirely negative at a time when urgent action on carbon emissions is overdue. 
Carl Sagan perfectly sums up humanity‚Äôs present predicament when he said,
‚ÄúThe dumbing down of America is most evident in the slow decay of substantive content in the enormously influential media, the 30 s sound bites (now down to 10 seconds or less), lowest common denominator programming, credulous presentations on pseudoscience and superstition, but especially a kind of celebration of ignorance.‚Äù

text: Climate is a chaotic system which means the less complete the data set, the more the computer models will vary on long timelines. The number of assumptions involved in producing the models upon which this entire climate alarmism is based is enormous. There are some parameters we know affect climate and we can roughly guess at how these parameters affect overall climate, but there are other parameters we do not fully understand. We certainly do not fully understand the capacity of the world's oceans, for instance, to absorb carbon, or for the rise in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to spur plant growth and self-mitigate. All of these parameters are completely guessed at when formulating the models. No one can possibly deny this.

text:
Interviewer missed the most important point coming from almost all the contributors. Everything currently being done is futile.
Even if we can establish that the CO2 increase has made any measurable difference to climate..... and if we should assume that any warming is a bad thing......  what should we be doing to actually make a difference?
Human contribution to CO2 production is 1.1% of the total CO2 in the atmosphere..... and total CO2 is less than 0.045% of the entire atmosphere.
Poor people are not going to be helped by preventing them having energy to irrigate their deserts.
No islands are in danger of being flooded in the foreseeable future.
It is madness.

text:
So what is happening at the geographic poles? Arctic melting = more cold water escaping the north. Pole shift causing magnetic north pole to move towards Siberia = the cold waters of the Kara and East Siberian sea also moving into the Atlantic. As Siberia moves up to the new geographical northern point, the colder air of northern Siberia also moving towards the Atlantic. As North America moves south, the Jet stream is distorted by the cold water and air from the melting Arctic, the cold water from the Kara and East Siberian Sea as well as the northern tip of Siberia which has had -83 degrees recorded in winter 2017-18 and domestic and wild animals freezing to death, just as the many animals that froze to death in previous cold periods. 


As the tip of Argentina/Chile and Siberia migrate to the poles, these areas have seen colder winters. The pole shift has altered ocean temperatures as snow/ice melt has released more cold water from the poles upsetting ocean currents and the north/south jet streams. Colder air over Siberia is being pulled towards Alaska, Canada and the northern states of America with the spin of the planet and as the ocean and air circulation patterns in the northern hemisphere of the Pacific are deflected. The increased land area of Siberia holds and accumulates lower temperatures, unlike oceans which benefit from the circulation of warmer waters from the equator. Sadly this process will generate more and more regional extreme weather not only in the northern continents but also worldwide. South Africa which is moving anti clockwise has seen increased droughts and floods over the past few years for the same reason....pole shift. 


The pole shift has altered migration patterns of marine life, birds and animals. Then add the daily GPS correction of GPS locations of airports and add the fact that government and satellite industry colleagues have been told not to talk about pole shift. Then add the increase in skin cancers from the increase in UV levels in countries, particularly those nearer the equator like Australia as it approaches the equator. As the crust faces more and more stress, extinct volcanoes are erupting and earthquakes are increasing in number and intensity. Now more gases are escaping from fissures in deep ocean where the crust is thin, turning the oceans acidic and killing coral reefs. See Hundreds of vents leaking methane from the Atlantic sea floor.@  and Independant article @t  China is building ghost cities inland and at higher altitudes as well as in the west of China and in Africa, as ultimately eastern China will be in the Arctic.See China ghost cities @   Central an eastern Russia will also cross the Arctic and as the magnetic north pole moves inland, temperatures in Siberia will continue to fall, and the land surface will provide a suitable area for the increased cloud cover generated from the tropics, to fall and be stored on land, generating new massive glaciers and ice sheets. Governments have known about the pole shift for years! This is the beginning of the sixth extinction.

text: Just a few minutes ago I heard an academic state she had resigned from her university because research funding was only being granted for projects that were examining the detrimental effects of human behaviour on climate change. text: I am no expert on the subject. My understanding is that everybody agrees that CO2 is increasing and that temperatures in the first decade of the new Millenium seem to be higher than those of say the 1970's. The thing is that this does not prove that man is the cause. I have seen some academic presentations that suggest that the contribution of human CO2 is miniscule compared to the natural component. Moreover others are suggesting that heating has also occurred on other planets. Other still are suggesting that CO2 follows rather than leads temperature rise whilst other present considerable discrepancy between the climate models and real measurements. Other still suggest a good correlation between sunspots and global temperatures, others bring chlorine into the equation rather than CO2. If any these latter studies are validated, then irrespective of scientific consensus, humanity is climbing the wrong tree. If it is a predominantly natural phenomenon, reducing CO2 won't help, except to better safeguard finite resources and reduce dependency of fossil fuels.

text:
We live in an Ice Age! Our interglacial is merely one of dozens in this ongoing Ice Age. And from the Greenland ice core temperature proxies, it looks like the Holocene started to end about 3,000 years ago. Massive cooling trend, leaving our scary Modern Warm Period as the coldest of the Holocene's 10 warm periods, preceded by the coldest cool period -- the Little Ice Age.
The first effect of major Global Cooling is failed crops and food shortages. Eventually, rain becomes scarce, because cooler oceans don't evaporate enough. And storms get stronger and more frequent, like they did during the Little Ice Age (Ref: Dr. Hubert Lamb, first director of CRU at East Anglia).

text:
Lindzen is introduced as a "SKEPTIC" when in fact he is a REALIST.  It's amusing the narrator says skeptics are not scientists, then introduces a realist who IS a noted climate scientist.


The climate did warm.  Solar scientists state that it is now likely to cool and indeed there is some evidence that the predicted cooling may be beginning.


The impact of atmospheric carbon dioxide has been PROVEN to have been exaggerated - in fact the IPCC and noted climate alarmist "scientists" admitted that as the level of atmospheric carbon dioxide continued to increase the rate of surface warming decreased, despite claims that it MUST increase as atmospheric carbon dioxide increased.


Claims humans are driving the measured increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide tend to be refuted by the fact that temperature rises first and as it does, this causes both the oceans and the areas of the higher latitudes that were formerly subjected to year round permafrost conditions to change from net carbon sinks to net carbon sources.  This has been scientifically PROVEN, it's not a myth, it's a PROVEN FACT.  The contributions from ocean and land as the Earth warms normally and naturally is much greater than any human carbon dioxide production.  This is why, when the Earth warms and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere rises, the warming starts FIRST and the carbon dioxide increase comes AFTER.


My own research indicates that climate alarmists have been saying we must reduce human carbon dioxide emissions since at least the 1980s.  They've had well over 20 major conferences where they insist that if we don't reduce human carbon dioxide emissions NOW it will be too late, but the result of each meeting has been to agree to let them increase but to attempt to tax them and instead of using the money collected to reduce total carbon dioxide emissions, it was actually going to be used in ways that would help "developing countries" to increase their carbon output.  China, the world's #1 human carbon dioxide source BY FAR,  was allowed to greatly increase their carbon output and they did so by going on a crash program to build coal fired power plants, the absolute worst type when it comes to carbon dioxide and other emissions.

text: Is the apparent rise in greenhouse gases the only cause of rising sea levels?   Here is another point of view:  Astronomers have been showing us pictures of the events happening on the other planets of our solar system.   Two things stand out;  the axial tilt of most planets have changed with respect to the sun, and very obvious weather changes have occured.   The only logical and reasonable explanation for this is the presence of an outside gravitational force strong enough to affect all of the planets of our solar system, including our Earth.   The axis of our Earth has also changed.   The sun's gravity is what keeps the planets in their proper orbits.   When an axial tilt occurs the northern hemisphere gets closer to the sun during summertime, and further away during the winter.   This causes a redistribution of our atmosphere and ocean currents.   This is what is causing climate change and sea level changes, not man-made greenhouse gasses.   The melting ice at the poles and Greenland are but the "symptoms" of  temperature changes from the sun.   I grew up in the Los Angeles area and remember that at mid-summer the sun was exactly overhead, but never shined through north-facing windows.   Now, it's two weeks to the longest day of the year and the sun shines easily through my north-facing windows.   That is functional proof that the tilt axis of our Earth has changed.   I'm sure that NASA knows all of this, but that would go against the global warming theory.   Remember, 97% of all scientists on a government payroll agree with the global warming theory.
author: Ray Grant

text: The Sun transmits at an effective temperature of approximately 5800 K, with an emission spectrum, peaked in the central, yellow-green part of the visible spectrum.  Entering Earth's atmosphere, about 55% of the incoming sunlight is infrared photons. They strike the Earth and are reradiated back out into the atmosphere in the black body temperature range of 255K. The other 45% is white light and of that, about 30% of that is reflected back into outer space, which is what you would see from outer space looking back at the Earth. That should leave about 31.5% of the total light being white, to strike the Earth and be reradiated back into the atmosphere as Earth's black body 255k range of infrared photons. That would mean 55% infrared photons coming in and 86.5% total infrared photons going out. As we increase the secondary greenhouse gases, CO2, CH4, O3, N2O, CFCs and HCFCs, in the atmosphere,  we block more incoming infrared photons, slightly cooling off the planet.  Being there are more outgoing infrared photons than incoming, we trap more outgoing infrared photons than reflecting the incoming photons. That being said, all things being equal, on the mean, the planet must heat.

text: Now let us look at this from the secondary greenhouse gas CO2. One of CO2's properties is it has a reactive band in the 255K range where it absorbs and releases infrared photons in Earth's black body radiation range. Once released after absorption, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or down. Since the oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface, this gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water. Infrared photons will not penetrate a body of water's surface, but will instead excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the primary greenhouse gas which prevents the Earth from having a climate like our moon. Consequently, the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere, the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets. This is how a 46% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute humidity.  The present increase in temperature due to this combination of additional  H2O and CO2 with over a doubling of CH4, in the atmosphere is approximately .9C at present.  Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature equilibrium. If we continue to inject 37 gigatonnes annually of CO2 into the atmosphere, that heating process will continue to accelerate with .6C of additional heat already baked into the system.
author: EF M

text: The Arctic temperature is increasing at over twice the rate of the rest of the planet, decreasing the differential between the equator and the poles which correspondingly has been slowing down the Arctic jet stream. This is precisely what is allowing warm Pacific air to penetrate the Arctic, pushing the Arctic air into Central Asia and the North American continent. Consequently, as the rest of the planet heats, both Central Asia and the North American continent has been slightly cooling on the mean. The US's Eastern Seaboard has been getting especially hammered by frigid air. This is precisely why it is called climate change instead of global warming.
author: EF M

text:
Since there seems to be an issue with fossil fuels, the question is what to do about it. This is my answer. If anyone has a different solution, I'd like to hear it. Let's begin with BTUs out vs BTU in by the energy source. 
Corn 1.3 
Solar PV 9 
Natural gas 10
Windmills 18
Light Water Reactors 80
Coal 80
Hydropower 100
Molten Salt Reactor and Traveling Wave Reactor 2,000

Now, consider deaths per terawatt.
Coal 161
Oil 36
Biomass 12

Solar PV .44
Windmills .15
Hydropower .10
Light water reactors .04
Molten Salt Reactor and Traveling Wave Reactor .003
 This does not include the one to two million people that die from cooking with carbon-based fuels annually.  Solar ovens are by far the better way to go.
As you can see LFTRs and Traveling Wave Reactors are the most cost efficient and safest energy supply possible at this time. We should easily be able to reach $0.02 to $0.03 per kilowatt-hour. That brings the price of everything down substantially. Building small mass-produced modular breeder reactors would also make windmills and solar panels exceptionally cost-effective. Don't get me wrong, the initial investment will not be cost effective but will drop dramatically over time.  We could have the population producing the majority of their own energy leaving nuclear energy for industry. Or we can continue with this absurd global warming debate.
author: EF M

text: In 1971, Richard Milhous Nixon and administration ordered the shutdown of our only LFTR research facility without explanation other than ‚Äúbudget cut‚Äù. If it had been allowed to go forward, we could have begun mass producing small modular breeder reactors by 1980. Installed in a grid formation like the internet, it would have been virtually impossible to shut the grid down. IThis type of design would also go hand in hand with solar panels and windmills. BTUs out vs BTUs in, the ratio of an LFTR is about 2,000 to 1. The best solar panels today are about 9 to 1. If you build breeder reactors first and then use the electricity to build solar panels, you would get a multiplier effect of about 2,000 X 9 = 18,000 to 1. Divide that by a coal-fired power plant of about 80 to 1, you get an efficiency increase of about 18,000 / 80 = 225 times than that over coal. If we had made the switch back in the 1980's our standard of living would be over double what it is today because the cost of manufactured goods would have dropped dramatically and there would have been a massive overabundance of fossil fuels available.   So, if this is all true, why haven't we done anything about it?  Two primary reasons, money is better invested elsewhere at this time and inertia. What we need another Manhattan Project if we wish to save our own butts and for the generations to come.  There already are companies that are investing in this technology like, Flibe Energy, Transatomic Power Corporation, ThorCon Power, Terrestrial Energy, Molex Energy, Seaborg Technologies, Copenhagen Atomics, and Terrapower.
author: EF M

text:
In 1827 Jean_Baptiste Fourier first recognized the warming effect of greenhouse gases.
In 1859, John Tyndall did the original research on the physical properties of CO2.
In 1896, the first quantitative estimate of the effect of doubling atmospheric CO2 on the mean surface temperature of the Earth was made by Svante Arrhenius.  

In 1967,  Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences
 "Thermal Equilibrium of the Atmosphere with a given Distribution of Relative Humidity."
Manabe and Wetherald were the first to include all the main physical processes relevant to the problem, using a model that was no more complicated than necessary to achieve this. This led to much more realistic simulations and enabled the results to be explained in terms of processes which could be observed in the real world. 
Manabe and Wetherald made a number of other discoveries. First, the temperature of the stratosphere cooled markedly when carbon dioxide was doubled. This is the characteristic ‚Äúfingerprint‚Äù of increasing carbon dioxide: the troposphere warms and the stratosphere cools, as we have observed over the last 50 years.
author: EF M

text:
Having studied two related subjects at university few years ago, and a lot of material since (for and against) on this topic including reading key IPCC reports I have made my mind. 
I do find it interesting to hear opposing view, and being aware that others may not have benefit of exposure to the relevant papers or time to study them, I feel I should put my 2 cents worth for the benefit of others.
The topic is fought on fairly low level and appears on the surface to be matter of opinion. "Unfortunately" nature of Physics and reality means that not every theory and opinion can win.
What is needed is a way to convey dry numbers and observations into understandable information for the average member of the public. This is where some believe there is room for unqualified opinions.
Normally, this is where references are called in, but in this case of broadspeaking spillage of byist opinions there are simpler ways to point to irregularities and mistakes.

Overall after listening the debate I would say, this is a case of limited data misinterpreted by man of limited knowledge, for purpose of "saving our money" while coincidentally making some for himself.
Just another attempt to describe current climate change as same as the ciclical changes in the past and obfuscate reality by unqualified statements. 
Do watch the debate and then come to the points below. 

Issues: 
The amount of CO‚ÇÇÔ∏é emitted thus far has started but, did not yet produce the it's full potential, for example most of warming and change potential is accumulating in the oceans at the moment. 
The process is long (50 to 100 years if I recall well, do check figures independantly yourselves) and thus message is that if we stopped carbon emissions we would still have that long period of temperatures raising and associated volotilities. 
The fact that we still emit and in accelerated rate is just amplifying the speed toward "runaway" point where control and mitigation will be impossible.

15:35 He clearly doubts the opinion poles of scientists and declares they were influenced but, does not provide reference to who was influenced and by whom. 
This is pure speculation on the level of religeous dogma (we are expected to accept this as a fact without explanation) or conspiracy theory at best, and he clearly states seconds later that he has no explanation or basis for this opinion.

Stating that consensus is something to be scared and worried about, is silly at best. I find it reassuring and a sign that there is truth behind it.

20:49 Another "I do not know", (about financing). Denying industry funding is dillusional at best, but ultimately has no bearing at the real truth of the situation. Pure diversion for no valid reason.

25:19 "I have a feeling"....this man is not debating facts, he is diseminating his own fears around. Problem for psychiatrists, not meant to be disseminated but resolved privately with experts in the field.

Saying that they should (self defeting argument) but partly due to his efforts and of efforts of people like him and big industry fail to act improperly?

This would be funny if it was not tragic. He is using slowness of the process he is slowing down as proof that there is no need to act. Circular logic at best. Sad.

29:40 "This would only make us poorer" is revealing true nature of his issue and motivation. 
No, this will help us survive an put us hopefully on sustainable path. 
Yes current industry will have to be modified, but "economy' should stay far away from this. 
After all once we are gone...there will be no economy either. 
There are: 
Real values- land minerals water, clean air etc. 
Moral values- rules for living in civilised, organised society and 
Invented/ficticious (agreed) values - money is ....nothing real, yet we put "price" on real values and destroy them, even judge if it is worth saving real values for the sake of "economy" and money? 
This is as stupid as one can get. Magnitudes of order more stupid than supposed exchange of Manhattan by Indians for some shiny necklesses.

Are we supposed to be that stupid? 
Are we really that stupid? I noticed no one laughed when he said these things, perhaps we are....

31:00 Proposal to wait and not do anything is a sentence for most and most irresponsible. Mathematics of early, delayed and late action is clearly calculated in IPCC documents.(Unqualified call to irresponsible stupidity)

35:00 "Alarmists (call for climate action) case is based on models only" False, models are used for future development prognosis. Explained sufficiently, read relevant papers. (False statement attempting to discredit someone else's hard work without explanation)

author: Peter Ozanne

text:
¬†@Peter Ozanne¬† I built two identical green houses side by side without roofs.
 The walls were twenty foot high and sealed with sealed doors.
 I put  temperature probes  and wide band oxygen sensors in both of them.
 I hooked up a pipe to the exhaust of a diesel engine powered welding machine and filled one green house with exhaust until the oxygen needed to survive in the semi enclosed structure was depleted.
 I did this for two weeks.
 The temperature inside of both structures were the same at anytime I checked, night or day.
   There was no evidence of a green house effect from burning fossil fuels in my experiment.
 As far as I know I am the only person in the world to ever conduct this type of experiment.
 So what ever is causing the earths temperature to rise is not a result of burning fossil fuels.

text: Attributing 300,000 deaths from extreme weather events to global warming is, as Lindzen says, specious. During the mediaeval warm period, when in Europe it was warmer than now, Greenland supported farming and vineyards thrived in England, Europeans thrived and the great cathedrals were built. The arrival of the "mini ice age" and the solar "maunder" minimum , caused widespread famine, the plague, and political upheaval. Half the population of Europe perished. None of the IPCC models factor in the various solar cycles. We are heading towards a new solar minimum. Global cooling will be much more difficult to confront than another half degree of warming.

text:
¬†@Justin Watkins¬† 
The most urgent measures to slow climate disruption are to 
- stop population growth and migration to developed nations. Educated citizens of developed nations have decreased their natural birth rate, but then Marxists in their perpetual power grab, want to increase immigration from the undeveloped world...and these people continue to breed at a higher rate....which exposes the subversive motive of the left. 
- replace coal power with nuclear and renewables. Interestingly, it was the same fear mongering left who opposed nuclear power from the 70s onwards. 
- reduce animal consumption and increase plant based diets. 
- reduce transportation needs by producing more goods and services locally. If you looked the transportation needs of the Amish, they'd possibly be as low as 5% of their neighbors. 

- town planners should make all cities more bicycle and pedestrian friendly, and public transport safer....which is unlikely in the USA due to diversity of values and poor lifestyle choices by a significant number. 
The USA has been brainwashed of what constitutes a stable, peaceful, and prosperous society. It isn't multiculturalism or multiracial (there's never been  successful examples).
Climate disruption should be the least of concerns for the USA. The private business and education sectors are throwing billions at research into better energy storage tech. Having the govt throw more money would be no doubt wasted and go to second rate researchers or rorts for mates.  
- the other great tech that will make a difference is nuclear fusion. but that also has the best brains in the world beavering away. There's only so many brains that understand this stuff, and throwing more tax dollars at the problem won't necessarily shorten the development of it. 
So once again, if the left are so anxious about climate change, then let them go vegan, sell their cars, stop flying, and live in communities that grow most of their food. 
Either way, the USA only produces 15% of greenhouse gases, so the climate alarmist narrative is a crock. It's actually deplorable that the standard of debate and information about climate change is so fake and naive. It's hard to believe the USA is among the most educated nations on the planet.

text: They are asking the wrong question. Has man caused climate change is of interest only to historians. The RIGHT question is, if CO2 has caused warming and/or change, what will happen in the future if we keep adding more CO2? The answer appears to be: Not much, because the CO2 that has already been put into the atmosphere now absorbs MOST of the infrared that CO2 can absorb, so putting 100 times as much would likely not double the effect. In short, even if man-made CO2-based global warming/change is as real as the iPCC says it is, we are NOT looking at some sort of future catastrophe by putting lots more CO2 into the atmosphere. So far, I haven't heard ANYONE disputing this point of view - which seems to be a MUCH more important question to ask than asking how we got here (now with 4% of 1% of the atmosphere being CO2). Any challengers?

text:
I am not a scientist having been to University or College don't have degrees,  but what I do have is basic common sense.  which tells me the space I live in is not endless so therefore it's only logical that you can't endlessly put something into it, regardless of what that thing is you wish to endlessly put into it.


 a limited space is a limited space no matter how big or small it is, it is still governed by the same laws of physics,  which states you cannot endlessly put something into something that is not endless. 


 apparently I'm the only one that understands that,    the human race is living in this confined space  and to show  that they understand where they live  they base their policies on endless growth  and then turn around and say is climate change fact or fiction.


 if you live in a confined space and this confined space as an ecosystem,  it is not like the confined space of your cup  which doesn't need to share its limited space with anything other than what you wish to put in it.     out ecosystem it relies on balance,  it is that balance that keeps everything in order that allows life to form and exist.

I am totally lost.

Climate Change is not caused by one single initiating force.     The combination of the Industrial Revolution,  Over-zealous Nuclear Testing throughout the late 20th century, and our Post-modern/Post-Y2K lifestyles having softened us, even with the Climate/s of War and conflict around the globe.


Air Conditioning, Increases in CO2, Orbiting closer to the Sun (NASA wont' tell you that), and our increased consumption of Caffeine and Sugar all lead to the feeling that it seems to be getting hotter.

It is indisputable that at higher levels of carbon dioxide plants grow faster and bigger.
How many people are saved from famine by global warming?

At  some significant percentage all animals die.   So what is the optumum?


Is the temperature of the earth at an optinum for maximum life?
Clearly, if Siberia were warmer more life could exist there, but would life become impossible at the equator?


The temperature of the earth has varied considerably of the lifetime of the earth.  We have gone through different ice ages several times, before humans lived on earth.  But in between the ice ages we have had warm periods.  Do climate scientists understand how these climate changes occur?  Surely, if they cannot explain those, then small perturbations in the system caused by carbon dioxide changes may be totally irrelevent.

text: The climate hasn't changed much since the last time it changed, its cloudy today and it might be sunny tomorrow. But those are the last glaciers in North America. There used to be a glacier in Yosemite, but if there still is, you can make a small ice skating venue out of it. The lakes at 5000'-6000' used to freeze over the surface solid in the 70's 80's, and decades before. They don't do that anymore, since the locals and old timers can remember. There used to be eight to ten feet of snow at 3000-3500' elevations, it's barely a few feet at most melted off in two days. I haven't stepped on a car under the snow in years. Fortunately though recent snow levels have been drought busting. And if enough volcanoes blow their tops, it might be enough to lay down glacial layers of ice sheets.

author: Fred Bloggs

text:
*Optimum.*. Considering most life on Earth today evolved in the 350ppm range, or has adapted to it, that would arguably be the optimum for most life. Plants like CO2, yes, they need it to live, they don't like drastically increased heat and erratic precipitation.

The Holocene was very stable, plants enjoyed relatively cyclic and stable growing conditions.  That's what they like.  Anywho...

Yes, current projections say that Siberia will get a bit greener, and life will become impossible at the equator for weeks at a time, which essentially means all year.  Most the flora and fauna doesn't migrate, so a few weeks spiking into dangerous levels of heat will literally kill it off.  This is the accepted cause of coral bleaching.
author: Cani Terrae

text:
Addendum, yes, they have very very detailed models about how the climates of various epochs of the Earth came about and changed.  It's literally what Geology is about.  It's also a very fun and interesting subject, I highly recommend reading about it.  It's like entering a time machine.  Super fun.

These are good questions you raised.  There are answers, though.

text:
Kevin Skipper   No, I have no need listening to egos quarrel to delude themselves they're right ‚Äì with a heavily biased arbitration ‚Äì especially since the debate/quarrel is entirely moot. 

Only symbolic gestures will be made until the alleged problem perhaps becomes undeniable. That is just how politics works. I have my own evaluation and it's probably right as usual, but that doesn't matter either ‚Äì not beyond a small group of friends and relatives who value my take on things.

I'm want to being right so early on about a whole slew of developments, I gradually lost the will to try to convince others and restricted myself to formulate a comprehensible outline in order to initiate awareness with those, who were ready and motivated for battle.

I also don't consider the sport of making predictions much more than adult infantilism ‚Äì when it comes to public debates and politics. In real science, predicting can act as a test of validity of theory, of course, but in real life entirely different forces and conditions are at play. 

One important dynamic often ignored is the feedback mechanism between the motive for ‚Äì and the effect of ‚Äì any  prediction,  which nevertheless quite often leads to the paradox of the best predictions nullifying themselves, leading to the possible later interpretation, that "we thought the problem serious, but our concern turned out to be exaggerated" ;)

How do we even know afterwards if some apparently sufficient measures were really necessary? 

Scenarios we couldn't imagine might have played out (leading to conditions half would deem better, the other half worse) had we acted differently, but might in any case already have changed the future in ways nobody could foresee ‚Äì even to such a degree as to change the number of available options later on.

And again people differ: Some prefer less options and a paved road ‚Äì others are forever off-roaders looking for untried solutions...

text: Lindzen is a shill for big oil who collects $2,500 each time he speaks. He underestimates climate sensitivity. We've measured a 40% increase in CO2 and have observed a temperature increase which arguably is in excess of 1 C over the 1750 baseline. The last 5 years have been the hottest years in meteorological history and some months these past two years have gone beyond 1.5 C in the northern hemisphere. Clearly, Charney's estimate of climate sensitivity of 3 degrees per doubling is very accurate. Another failing of Lindzen is his complete ignorance of ecosystems, biology, and agronomy in general. A 3 C increase will translate into a apocalyptic 6 C increase over our grain belts during the summer and an estimated 25% decrease in yields from photorespiration alone. Add increasing insect herbivory, an insanely unpredictable jet stream, heat waves and drought and we could very well be looking at a 50% reduction in yields in just 20-30 years. How could we have been so foolish as to do practically nothing these last 30 years? Just look around at what is happening already!

text:
You are right spex357. I did an experiment many years ago and the results was different than what experts continue to push. I made 4 seal-able glass containers and placed a thermometer in each one. I then removed all the air out of every container (vacuum). In the first container I added carbon dioxide. In the second container I added water vapor. In the third container I added nitrogen. In the forth container I added just air. 

One would think that if CO2 was a major greenhouse gas the air inside the container holding the CO2 would have gotten warmer than the rest seeing how the concentration was about 98% CO2 in the container, not the 0.00041%  currently in the atmosphere. But the container with the CO2 was cooler than all the other containers. I didn't paint the bottom of the containers black like what had been done with other experiments because I did not want the black background to skew the results. And sure enough the container that held the water vapor got the hottest, not the CO2. Empirical evidence that water vapor is the major greenhouse gas not CO2.

text:
The MIT professor is by no means the only Scientist of high standing who is anti hysterical on Climate Change. Dr Soon and Dr Patrick Moore (Co founder of Green Peace) have higher profiles and are more photogenic than this professor. They explain and definitively trace Climate Change without the Hysteria. The responsibility for Climate Change rests with the Sun üåû Political intervention is clearly providing a bias, fuelling the hysteria of the general public, whilst creating new demand for alternative energy production. You reduce CO2 by consumption. Therefore, the objective must be to increase forestry, which consumes CO2. Historically, the planet called Earth has experienced more than 10 times the current CO2 levels in comparatively recent geological times.
Methane is the real danger, which would increase the effects of Climate Change by a factor of 30 times greater that of the highest projected level of CO2, 200 years from now at the current estimated production rate. Examples of hypocrisy is exemplified with Germany currently building 30 new Coal Fired Power Stations, because they made a Political decision to remove nuclear power. Therefore, this demonstrates to China, India and the developing 3rd World the hypocrisy of our Carbon emission controls program and the Hysteria being created to justify the demand for them to change.
The Volcanic Activity around the World represents a far greater risk to Climate Change and Potentially Catastrophic loss of human life, dependant upon the level of emissions, which cannot yet be determined. What this program demonstrated to me was that the media having generated by its projection of the percentage of scientists supporting the Climate Change Hysteria argument, has distorted the Scientific Facts available for analysis, including accurate modelling, which can‚Äôt be based on a 40 or 100 year caption period.
The European Union by specifying the level of Volcanic Ash permitted in the atmosphere before aeroplanes would be grounded, due to safety concerns was accepted by everyone as a good thing. Then having to raise that acceptable level of ash by over 300% when the level would not conveniently drop back quickly enough through natural process. Remember also that you exhale 4% CO2 from the air you breath and if it where not present in the atmosphere you wouldn‚Äôt be able to breath at all. Methane stored in the Earth is a far greater issue than CO2 production when it comes to Greenhouse Gases.
A Greenhouse Blanket Ash and even of Volcanic Ash has been the major factor in Historical Climate Change. Last point: at levels of below 150 parts per million (ppm) CO2 in the atmosphere, no life can exist on the Earth, nothing will grow, you will have nothing to eat and everything dies, including you! author: J Stenberg

text:
¬†@J Stenberg¬† There is no doctoring of paleo climate history...  It is what it is and it's been confirmed in many different ways.


For the last 800,000 years the earth has been cycling from ice age to interglacial period, back and forth for dozens of times in that period.

Why?

Because of the wobble and orbit of the earth around the sun in conjunction with the cycling of the sun through various active and inactive stages. 

The wobble and orbit at cyclical points makes it so that much colder temps can reign supreme and pushes the world into an ice age as a result.  Man will never be able to control this aspect of the climate, we are destined to enter another ice age in about 10,000 years or so. 

During those 800,000 years, the CO2 levels in the atmosphere vacillated between 200 and 280 ppm.
When the earth was deep in the throes of an ice age, the CO2 levels dropped into the 200 ppm range.  Why? 

Because LESS of the land above sea level was available for animals and man to live on. Less animals on the planet means less CO2 being generated via respiration, and the CO2 levels drop. 

When the earth was in an interglacial period, much like where we find ourselves today, the CO2 levels increased and rose up into the 280 ppm range.  Why? 

Because MORE of the land above sea level became available for animals and man to move into and live, population levels rose, and CO2 levels rose as a result. 

In 1860, the CO2 levels on the earth were measured to be about 260 ppm.  THIS MAKES SENSE WHEN CONSIDERING THE PREVIOUS 800,000 YEARS OF CLIMATE HISTORY 

Last year, the CO2 levels on the earth were measured at a little over 410 ppm. 

What the heck changed? 

Why are CO2 levels so much higher, 130 ppm higher than what history tells us they SHOULD be based on the history of the last 800,000 years?  We SHOULD be around 280 ppm, yet here we are at 410 and rising. 

The answer is obvious.  The only thing that has changed between the historical levels of CO2 and what they are today is mankind's development of and use of cars and commercial vehicles, and mankind's development and use of coal powered electricity generating plants operating 24/7/365. 

Newtonian physics teaches us an important lesson, and that is this.  For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. 

You can't increase the density of CO2 in the atmosphere, and expect for the climate to stay the same.

author: David Kirkpatrick

text:
Climate change is a fact. As it has been since the dawn of times. 
Global warming in the recent past is a fact. Its root causes are complex and the trend is very uncertain. Predictive models keep being proven wrong.

Desertification is a real problem, where "modern" agricultural practices are about a million times more guilty than CO2. 

Throwing money at the problem by making a bold and expensive gamble on the root causes and possible remedies is the easy way. 

Sustainable, intensive agriculture, molten salt reactors, and better governance have much more to contribute to the safe future of mankind than wind and possibly sunpower, even if the latter, in sunny, cloudfree  climates, has real traction. 

Further centralisation of political and administrative decision making would only deprive mankind of competition between various practices. 
Que le meilleur gagne !

text:
¬†@Tatrer¬† All right, thats fair i suppose. You wanna be serious? Fine, i'll indulge you, let's be serious then.

Did you know that increases in CO2 have a detrimental effect on plantlife biodeversity in nature?

As PPM concentrations increase,  plants require more water and sunlight to thrive. Since plants in nature compete with eachother for both water and sunlight by outgrowing eachother and taking up more space vertically and horizontally, the benefits of invreased CO2 would benefit some species and be detrimental to others. The loss of diversity may be disruptive to the biosphere in ways we don't fully understand yet.


Ofcourse we mostly care about crops, as nice as forests may be, its the food that we need more than preventing erosion or conserving wildlife habitats.

And since crops are mostly artificial monocultures that dont need to compete with other plants, they'll be able to boom in mass and we'll have more food than ever right?

Like in those pictures of people growing trees in greenhouses with differrent PPM's and holding signs in front of themselves on which the number for CO2 PPM grows in paralel to the tree behind them?

Or maybe those graphs that show various harvest yields clearly growing as PPM increases? 

Welp, that's all very good and true, in isolation, where you can supply those plants with the additional water and nutrients and energy they need for additional CO2 to have effect.Anyone that's had an interest in home growing under controlled artificial day/night cycles via Lamps in order to control a plant's vegetative and reproductive states can tell you that intentionally increasing CO2 also must go hand in hand with proportional control of water, nutrient and light feeds as well as ph controll depending on the growth base.

But in mass agriculture, your bottleneck isnt CO2. It's usually water and stable weather. Even if you could keep up with feeding and watering your now faster growing crops, you'd use up more resources for that production, and in agricultural irrigation and fertilitation, scarce water and fertilizer prices follow supply and demand dynamics.

So no, I don't think we're saving the plants and life that depends on them by pumping out fossil fuel CO2 in the atmosphere at a ludicrously accelerated pace.

The whole notion that the biosphere will ultimately benefit from the abrupt changes we are making to the atmosphere is absurd.

text: So I am a little confused about the 97% consensus among climate scientists. I have heard that a temperature increase of 1.5 degrees is survivable, but an increase of 5 degrees will bring about the catastrophe.  And I have also heard that almost all of the models have predicted higher temperatures than have actually happened for the last 15 years.  I beleive the problem is real, I just can't tell if it is an imminent existential threat, or if we have a little time to make the needed changes in an orderly manner?

text:
I know nothing about climatology, though I do have a science background (U. Toronto).  I am thus lost in this ongoing debate and have little to offer, except to relate, if it's worth anything, the somewhat inspiring example of those two Australians who won the Nobel Prize for medicine in 2005, and those who preceded them in their work.  For years, 97% of scientists working in gastric medicine pointed to an established consensus that acid causes peptic ulcers and  they rejected and personally shunned those few researchers who felt their work showed that a spiral bacterium, H. Pylori, was the culprit.  They were right, of course, and now we take antibiotics for stomach ulcers, which are cured by them.

In my view, that story offers a chance to learn some very important things about science, life, and people.  It was very much in my mind as I watched the treatment offered to Dr. Lindzen.
author: dixon pinfold

During this debate, no single word about the sun, the main source of heat and solar cycles, Milankovitch cycle, planetary alignment cycle, ...
Each day, 170 million Gigawatts, over 7 thousand times the power that humanity consumes rains down on Earth surface triggering a wave of activity that never ceases. So if the sun activities such as the coronal mass ejection (CME) and the sunspots activities fluctuates how it is possible to believe that Earth climate and weather, the plants and other lives are not affected by the sun. The CME frequency of ejections depends on the phase of the solar cycle: from about one every fifth day near the solar minimum to 3.5 per day near the solar maximum.

What is clear from the study of past climate is that many recipes of factors can influence climate: solar activity, oscillations in Earth‚Äôs orbit, Lunar modulation, greenhouse gases (95% H2O, 0.05% CO2), ice cover, vegetation on land (or the lack of it), the configuration of the continents, Ocean current change, heat/dust thrown up by asteroids, volcanoes or wind, the weathering of rocks, applied technologies,  planetary/gas giants alignment, stars alignment, galactic alignment, solar system travelling through different cosmic forces, across different elements, and so on.

text:
¬†@2ndtonone1000¬† You said something that's false. Most of the CO2 in the atmosphere is NOT caused by man-made emissions, however before climate change deniers cream their pants at this fact... most of the INCREASE in atmospheric CO2 IS caused by man-made emissions. So for instance, if you have 100 tons of CO2 repeatedly going in and out of a system, that is a balanced, carbon-neutral system. Carbon goes in, carbon comes out... So there is no increase in CO2. But if you repeatedly add 1 ton of surplus CO2 to that previously balanced, neutral, background cycle... even though you have only contributed <1% of the CO2, you are still 100% repsonsible for the total increase in CO2. Turning a previously carbon-neutral system into a carbon-positive system. The longer you do this, the more devastating the effects on the stability of the system.

THAT is the issue. There is no magical phenomenon that will magically remove the extra CO2 we've added. The current carbon cycle is a naturally stable system (hence why we evolved and flourished during a time of relative climate stability on the earth) but if we INTRODUCE unnecessary instability into the system that wasn't previously there, it's not going to magically stabilise itself. If we inadvertently add instability, we have to also add stability to counteract and fix it.
author: ag

text: ¬†@ag¬† You are correct, an my apologies for not stating that, but you are correct. I have these arguments all the time, and it's easy to mislead an deny, then state the facts that are constantly ignored an cherry picked by climate deniers.
author: 2ndtonone1000

text: ¬†@2ndtonone1000¬† It's all good. Besides, it's a good opportunity to explain WHY even a small surplus to the amount of CO2 still results in an entirely anthropogenic cause for climate change. It's a common myth that if we contribute only a small % of the atmospheric CO2, then nature is the main driver of increased temperature rather than us. It's such a fundamental misunderstanding of what's driving the problem we're seeing, but sadly it spreads because it sounds convincing when you don't actually understand the nuance. It'd be like saying a business's success should be measured purely by its gross turnover rather than its net profit.

It will be far too late in 50 years! Lindzen knows nothing about biology or plant physiology. If we hit 3 C in 40-50 years (perhaps sooner as we've heated the earth by 1 C already) which is possible now then agriculture in our grain belts will suffer very significant reductions due to photorespiration. Temps above 93 F or 33 C produce a reduction in net photosynthate due to photorespiration. Also, pollination in corn and rice fail at 95F that is why Indiana and Illinois had such deplorable harvests in 2012. That April was the highest global monthly average temp for an April ever recorded and 1/2 the counties in the US were in drought- 30 billion in crops were lost. It is absurd to think that the US will be the breadbasket of the world in 30-40 years if we continue on this path. Remember, it is always hotter over land than over ocean during the summer. +3 C world is incompatible with agriculture at scale and crop production will be reduced by 25-50% so commodities market fails while food prices skyrocket. Chaos will be the political order of the day- it will be an ungovernable world especially when we consider that many aquifers are already depleted and we are already observing changes in the distribution of rainfall and the monsoons. This is no trifling matter Lindzen. You should be ashamed of yourself. Learn some biology.

text: Lindzen quote (1989): "the likelihood over the next century of greenhouse warming reaching magnitudes comparable to natural variability seems small"  Natural variability, over the last 22,000 years, is 0.014C/century (mean) with SD=0.077C/century, so any century with a change greater than 0.24C/century (=3*SD) is flirting with the label "unnatural".  Yet in the 20th century, warming was 0.78C/century, and since Lindzen made that remark, the rise has been ~2.2C/century.  It's OK for Lindzen to be horribly wrong in 1989.  The problem is he maintains the same position today, 28 years later.  That's a really long time to be wrong about something, and to be forgiven for being wrong.

text:
Dr. Lindzen was a member of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, but takes issue with the general conclusions drawn from the IPCC's report. His prolific writings assert that climate change science is inconclusive, and has testified multiple times before Congress.

Ross Gelbspan reported in 1995 that Lindzen "charges oil and coal interests $2,500 a day for his consulting services; his 1991 trip to testify before a Senate committee was paid for by Western Fuels, and a speech he wrote, entitled 'Global Warming: the Origin and Nature of Alleged Scientific Consensus,' was underwritten by OPEC." ("The Heat is On: The warming of the world's climate sparks a blaze of denial," Harper's magazine, December 1995.) Lindzen signed the 1995 Leipzig Declaration.

text:
One does not have to be forced to accept a theory, but science as a society tends to ignore or marginalize ideas that contradict mainstream views even in the enlightened modern era. Even the theories of genetics established by Mendel were suppressed till it was rediscovered years after his death. 

To be scientific, we need to recognize that the current theory of climate change is a "hypothesis" that needs to come up with testable predictions and conclusions. Otherwise, one can always say that skyscrapers in America are so tall that people in the top floor can soon start to have conversations with the astronauts and people on Ellis island may believe it. 

A problem with the alarmist movements is that it fails to recognize that the earth's CO2 concentration was much higher (over ten fold) in geological time, and both plants and animals were healthy. Toxic doses of CO2 are about 150 times the levels in the atmosphere. The total CO2 in the atmosphere is about 3E12 tonnes, and living organisms fix about 2.5E11 tonnes or 8% of the total atmospheric CO2 per year and this fixation goes up with temperature and CO2 concentration, and therefore the greenhouse effects of releasing CO2  should be tempered by vegetation. If anything I may argue that the solution is to plant grass on rooftops and all open spaces to increase the fixation. 

Disclaimer: I am not a climate scientist, but am simply trying to grasp the facts and understand the reason for the international alarmist movement.

text:
Richard Lindzen has been totally discredited. 
He gets money from dubious fossil fuel sources and uses out of context data and he's retired and not up to date  in the cutting edge of research. 

No scientist has ever said that climate doesn't change. 

The issue is the acceleration. A one degree change within a century is enormous compared to the global average only fluctuating between 10 and 25 degrees over 500 million years. 
The change is even estimated to be 20 times faster than the recent emergence from the ice age. 
14 degree average to 15 degree average is of huge concern especially if it continues at that rate on a degree per century. 

There is a reason that the poles and Greenland are melting including all the glaciers on planet earth.
This  rate of change hasn't happened before except for catastrophic events like the asteroid killing the dinosaurs. 
How will this increasing melt water affect our coastal megacities ? 


Richard Lindzen doesn't care. He gets his brown envelopes and will  be dead soon.

text:
Bogus video! First of all, it's a misuse of a scientific term. "Climate change is a fact" is like saying gravity is a fact, or air is a fact. Climate has changed for nearly 4.5 billion years. Nothing new about that. Rise in temperature is man made? Also bogus. We just came out of the Little Ice Age. Our Holocene has had a warm period once every 1,000 years or so. The modern warm period has been the coolest of the ten! (Ref: Ole Humlum, Oslo U.)

How do we know the modern is the coolest warm period? The second coolest warm period was the Medieval Warm Period. During that period, about 1,000 years ago, Vikings grew crops in Greenland where it's still too cold to do so, today. The English farmers of the Medieval period could grow wine grapes where they cannot, today. See? These facts are easy to verify.

Why would people lie about "climate change?" First, you have to understand who started the "climate change" hoax and what kind of people they are. Biggest Oil Rockefellers started this scam through their UN front man, the late Maurice Strong (Canadian big oil). They're clever, but psychopaths. They're into eugenics and "sustainability" at the cost of billions of human lives. They're promoting global cooling in an ongoing Ice Age. That should wake you up!

text:
From the IPCC regarding HURRICANES:
"Current data sets indicate no significant observed trends in global tropical cyclone frequency over the past century and it remains uncertain whether any reported long-term increases in tropical cyclone frequency are robust, after accounting for past changes in observing capabilities. No robust trends in annual numbers of tropical storms, hurricanes and major hurricanes counts have been identified over the past 100 years in the North Atlantic basin."

From NOAH regarding TORNADOES:
"To better understand the variability and trend in tornado frequency in the United States, the total number of EF-1 and stronger, as well as strong to violent tornadoes (EF-3 to EF-5 category on the Enhanced Fujita scale) can be analyzed. These tornadoes would have likely been reported even during the decades before Doppler radar use became widespread and practices resulted in increasing tornado reports. The bar charts below indicate there has been little trend in the frequency of the stronger tornadoes over the past 55 years."

From the IPCC regarding DROUGHTS:
"In summary, the current assessment concludes that there is not enough evidence at present to suggest more than low confidence in a global-scale observed trend in drought or dryness (lack of rainfall) since the middle of the 20th century, owing to lack of direct observations, geographical inconsistencies in the trends, and dependencies of inferred trends on the index choice. Based on updated studies, AR4 conclusions regarding global increasing trends in drought since the 1970s were probably overstated."

From the IPCC regarding FLOODS.
"In summary, there continues to be a lack of evidence and thus low confidence regarding the sign of trend in the magnitude and/or frequency of floods on a global scale."

text: I must say this debate left me none the wiser. So many issues were not tackled. Deforestation, overfishing and local ecological destruction. Why does everything have to be considered on a planetary level? Clean energy sounds great to me even if the only thing it does is allow me to breath cleaner air in my own city, with no planetary consequences, good or bad. Maybe oil spillages have no impact on the global system but I definitely don't want to live in an area affected by one. And I don't get Lindzen's argument when people asked him what happens if he's wrong? He's basically saying it doesn't matter anyway because the measures we're taking to slow down climate change are merely "symbolic" and don't really produce any meaningful change. I actually agree with him and it's pretty obvious that whatever measures have been implemented so far clearly fall far short of what would be necessary to have any meaningful impact. But he might want to ask himself whether one of the reasons they are still symbolic and are likely to remain so, is because of people like him who encourage others to do nothing. And does that mean he would come out in support of clean energy if it actually was having an impact?

We are talking about science of TODAY.  The majority of the climate change deniers of TODAY (an issue that is all about what is happening TODAY) are not even scientists by today's standards.  Those who are scientists and still deny climate change have expertise an an area other than climate science so their "expertise" is not as trustworthy because their knowledge of climate science is not as extensive.  In fact, even these deniers have moved from denying climate change exists to acknowledging it exists but denying it is because of humans or just saying it is too expensive.  It's too expensive to save the human race?  Right.

If you want to talk about the people who are "sucking on the taxpayer", take a look at the rich who want lower their taxes at the expense of the rest of us and the antiquated big oil and coal that is trying to deny science and climate change.  These are the people who are toxic and need to be purged from society.  You have been brainwashed by these vile individuals.  Scientists are trying to make things better because the actually understand that making the world better for others does the same for them and the ones they love.  Meanwhile, the ignorant or self interested rich oil and coal mongers are teaching people like you to support your own demise.

text:
It's a sad sign of today's debating that a poor moderator is usually involved.

Mr Hassan's contunuous interruptions are a great irritation; and they disrupt the flow of important information. He keeps blocking real input by inserting questions just when the debater is making sense. If he would only allow the person to finish making the point, the experience of watching such debates would be a pleasure - instead, I found myself flipping to the next section where he was not speaking...

He's overrated as a moderator; and as a journalist.

It might be politically incorrect to make this point, but it seems to me - and to many observers of Mr Haddan's performances in both roles - that his status as a "sought-after journalist" on so-called controversial topics is due to his being a somewhat "acceptable" Muslim reporter, which is demonstrably a scarce resource in this multicultural, identity-group conscious world.

As a person who should be interested in reason, logic and evidence, he made himself (immediately) irrelevant as a debating host/moderator, when he made it clear to Dawkins that he did not question Mohammad's Pegasus ride to the moon...

His many comments defending Islam are not doing him or the TV networks who use him any favours; and his insistence on keeping control has grown as his confidence has grown over the years.

If I see him as a moderator, I usually move on.
