text: Cutting down on air pollution, water pollution, and food and soil pollution is a practical thing to do, and should be a top priority for all governments, businesses and individuals. However, the idea that by reducing or even eliminating pollution, we will therefore convert an ever-changing system, into a system that only changes the way we want it to, sounds like a plot for a Hollywood science fiction movie. It's a bit like fleas on the back of an elephant trying to prevent the elephant from taking a bath. We're like those fleas. We can't change the climate of a whole planet. We're just not there yet. Maybe after we terraform Mars 100 years from now. meanwhile, let's do what we can to preserve a decent pollution-free environment for our children and grandchildren and stop making wild claims that we can control the climate of planets.

author: Suel Koka

text:
Concensus is the final stage in the process of true science. The question of whether global climate change is real or not is a scientific question that has ripened to the point of concensus. It is the stage when after years of collecting data, reducing it, discussing the results and critically checking each other's work, all scientists come to an agreement. In the march of science, this is when scientists accept the fact as something they can rely on for further study. It is there with the fact that the Sun rises and sets because of the Earth's rotation. We don't need to collect and analyze any more data on that. It's established. We move on. Climate change is getting to the point where a lay person with internet access and eyes (or other ways for access) can also see that it's happening.

The climate scientists are no longer asking whether there is climate change or not. They are moving on to more questions, such as "how fast is this happening", "what can we expect over the next 50 years", "what are the implications for the species on Earth", "what can we do at this junction in time to mitigate the damage". They are pairing up with scientists from other fields and with policy makers to come up with practical solutions. And are being largely ignored, because our policy makers are still stuck on the question of whether climate change is happening or not. 

From my last interaction with climate scientists, I can tell you that the future is not rosy. We have reached the point where there is already too much CO2 in the atmosphere. That's a measured fact. We now need to not only really get on with cutting down on fossil fuel burning, but in addition, we must pump CO2 out of the atmosphere. There is an inertia there so even if we do these two things, the temperatures will continue to rise for a couple decades. Because we are already quite warm, we should also give very serious thought to short term emergency (but potentially dangerous and also expensive) measures such as putting up particles into the atmosphere to reduce incoming sunlight.

In parallel, there are things we can also do to the surface of the Earth to effect climate change, at the local and global level (things as simple as planting trees).

We are not doing any of that. And that's not just the US, with their heads firmly in the sand. Other nations have recognized for decades that this was happening and have been working on reducing their fossil fuel emissions, but they are not funding any research on pumping CO2 out of the atmosphere and other remediation. That realization has yet have to come. I worry that it will come too late and with large nations not getting on board, their efforts are doomed to failure.

As for consensus  you are consummately wrong. It was the consensus the sun revolved around the Earth but Galileo insisted on the facts and now we have a more perfect understanding.

text:
I'm sure you've seen this. https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/full.html I am putting this link here (noting that it comes from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) just so other people who might read our exchange do not get misled by whatever your second sentence means (it seems to imply that the content of CO2 in the atmosphere has not been growing since we started taking direct measurements in the 1960's - a statement that flies in the face of reality). Ice cores indicate that going further back in history, we surpassed the levels at the time the Earth was a tropical paradise and the dinosaurs roamed the Earth. 

Al Gore was not the only one talking about this. Other people since then have been talking about that, around the world. So let's not politicize this, it's a question of facing reality. I am not just listening, I am looking at the evidence with my own eyes and making my own observations. I can't help but worry when I shut off my furnace for a week at a time in February in PA, when my Mom in France tells me of a frost-free winter and invasions of caterpillars come spring, when we have a power outage when I visit due to a heat wave related fire at a transformer installation not built for that, and when bats in India fall out of the sky from heat stroke during catastrophic heat waves. And when climate scientists, who have been studying this for longer than I have and spend more time every day on this than I do talk, I listen to their expert opinion.

And to be fair to the skeptic in the video, he is not even questioning that global warming is happening. I don't think anyone honest with themselves does, anymore. What he is disputing is how much we should worry. At his age, probably not too much. At my age, more. For younger people, very concerning. He also doubts that we should bother taking the half-hearted measure we have been taking. I agree that they are not sufficient, but at least it's something. And if we start with something, we can do more. It's easy to throw our hands up and give up, but it is very dangerous to give in to despair, even if it appears to be the most natural course of action. I don't hold any hope about our ability to face this crisis, to be quite frank, but I still speak up whenever I can.

text: Again, you are not making sense. You can't absorb a spectrum, as a spectrum, obtained via a spectrograph, is a list of numbers used by scientists to make graphs and determine the properties of a gas such as composition and temperature, among other things. What you say sounds technical, but it mixes up concepts. Are you talking about the chemical process of saturation now, and saying that we're OK because the atmosphere cannot absorb more CO2 than it already has? There are two problems with that. 1) the CO2 already there has created a new equilibrium temperature for our planet that is above comfort levels. We have not reached that equilibrium temperature yet as that takes a few decades, but life on Earth will have to adapt to that and it's going to be painful since we forced a fast change. 2) we are far from saturation. Venus has an atmosphere that is 96% CO2 and a surface pressure equivalent to what we have in our deep oceans (an atmosphere 90 times more massive than ours). There is plenty of room for more CO2 in our atmosphere.

text: Bruce Frykman, I am not the one citing newspapers. I strongly believe that climate change and other scientific issues are independent of our political leanings. Nature does what it does, regardless of our respective positions and political motivations. By the way, I don't know of any country other than the US where climate change is a partisan issue. Everywhere else, it's a reality to be dealt with. I mentioned France before. I watched their 6 candidate presidential debate before the first round of elections. The moderators asked about climate change, to which the replies from all political candidates from far left to far right were brief and in the same direction. Yeah, big problem, need to do something about it. Some proposed solutions, some more radical than others. Interestingly, it is their republican candidate (moderate right in France) who proposed the politically most extreme idea: Amend the French constitution to make it a duty of its citizens to curb green house gas emissions and otherwise take remedial actions. He believed that unless France put that in their constitution, the government would be prone to do what it has been doing: taking half-assed actions (better than what we've been doing in the US, but still half-assed).

Kirk, I used to believe Al Gore's spiel, despite the fact that I had studied climate science starting in the mid-70s. Just enough half-truths to make it seem plausible. And plucking the emotion card of protecting our living space. But Gore avoided the fact that we currently live in an Ice Age and warming is the solution; not the problem. Cooling is the great danger that destroys civilizations and kills millions and potentially billions. Without warmth, the oceans don't let go of water. Without that water vapor, we don't have as many clouds. And without the rain from those clouds, crops fail. Hungry people get rowdy and dangerous.

Solution: Either warm up the planet on purpose (satellite reflectors; black tarps across the polar ice, etc.), or prepare for the coming glacial period. The end-of-interglacial cooling started about 3,000 years ago, if the Greenland ice core temperature proxies are any indication (Ref: Prof. Ole Humlum, Oslo U).

text:
To more effectively establish the terms of the debate, and to get actionable information, we could start by asking whether a democratic, global society should limit rates of putting carbon (or whatever) so that they do not exceed what most people think is acceptable... (?)

If we address problems of economic externalities (where costs of economic activity are foisted onto the larger society and future generations), we will end up charging fees or selling permits to those who emit (extract) carbon (or whatever). The proceeds should be shared equally among all the world's people. The policy of management and control of humans' impacts on the environment need not impoverish anyone. On the contrary, doing it right means ending poverty throughout the world.

When will news media present environmental and economic justice topics as being connected? They are both related to the question of whether we effectively address economic externalities and questions of equitable sharing of natural (commons) wealth.

text:
It's true that he personally believes climate change to be dangerous. But that's irrelevant because in this show he takes the position of arguing against his guest (who happens to be a climate change sceptic in this particular episode). Anyway, what's wrong with being passionate while debating as long as you keep your arguments sound? What's wrong with voicing your own opinion while backing it up with proper arguments and thus challenging the guest's view (which is the point of the show)?

Bias - a partiality that prevents objective consideration of an issue or situation.
(my dictionary says)

The partiality of the interviewer that is always present in Head to Head is not bias according to this definition. The guest defends some view and the interviewer challenges that view, which is precisely the instrument that makes the debate an objective consideration if done properly, i.e. via rational debate. And I'd argue that it is done properly.
author: Eivinas Butkus
